title: MARPOL Annex on Oil
headline: Learn how the MARPOL Convention helps ships prevent oil pollution in this free online course.
description: This free online course discusses the protocols of the MARPOL Annexes that make up the ‘International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships’. We examine the exemptions, applications and waivers to the Convention and explore its history of protecting our oceans. Oil spills can devastate marine life and these protocols play an important role in keeping the ‘Blue Planet’ blue.
courseDescription:
The 1983 MARPOL Annex I seeks to prevent oil pollution from ships and tankers and regulates the methods used to control the discharge of oil into marine environments. Oil is carried as cargo by tankers and used as fuel for marine diesel engines, which generates waste oil as unpumpable residue in cargo tanks and as sludge left over from the purification of fuel and lubricating oils. Drainage from fuel tanks, leaks from machinery operation and exhausted lubrication oils also collect in fuel and lube oil sludge tanks. These waste oils can all contribute to marine pollution when they are discharged into the sea during tank-cleaning operations or during the discharge of ballast taken into cargo tanks or as direct discharge from machinery space without the use of an oily-water separator (OWS). The widespread use of discharge-monitoring and control systems has contributed to a noticeable decrease in levels of marine oil contamination. The MARPOL convention introduced a number of radical new measures such as a requirement for new oil tankers to be fitted with segregated ballast tanks to remove the need to carry ballast water in cargo tanks. This was superseded by the requirement for oil tankers delivered from 1996 onwards to be fitted with double hulls, thus enhancing marine environmental protection.

This free online course teaches you the definitions, applications, port state controls (PSC) and reports contained in the articles of the MARPOL Convention. We also cover detection of violations, undue delay to ships and signatories’ general obligations. We study the applications and exemptions of MARPOL Annex I and delve into the various waivers and equivalents in cases where the applications of Annex I cannot be upheld while analyzing its survey requirements. We cover the condition assessment scheme (CAS) and programme (CAP) before laying out the duration and validity of the International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate (IOPP) and its various statutory clauses and requirements.

This course helps you understand marine pollution prevention methods and operations. We break down the requirements and conditions for machinery spaces as well as the usage of tools, amendments and exemptions to the norms governing tanks for oil residue. We take a close look at the conditions for the applications of oil fuel tank protection on tankers and vessels according to their position, state and capacity. We explain the basic functionalities of the bilge alarm and oil content monitor (OCM). Then follows the separation of oily water and the best practices and common errors associated with maintaining the oil record book (ORB). This course suits anyone looking to work in marine engineering, coastal conservation and maritime law as the MARPOL Convention plays a crucial role in protecting our precious oceans.

  • Introduction
  • Pollution at sea and in coastal waters is a problem. The MARPOL Convention was incorporated to address this problem and find solutions to reduce incidents of pollution. The objective of this convention is to primarily deal with oil pollution, besides other forms of pollution including pollution from chemicals, harmful substances, sewage, garbage, engine emissions, etc.

    IMO's marine pollution regulations have continued to include progressively expanding areas of pollution prevention from ships via its many annexes and protocols that are regularly added to the original convention; this is now known as the MARPOL which subsumes all other earlier conventions and has 6 Annexes.
    • MARPOL Convention - International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973
    • MARPOL 73/78 - International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1978
    • MARPOL - International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1997

  • Lesson Summary
  • The MARPOL Convention was structured to have the following subjects:
    • Protocol I: Reports on incidents involving harmful substances.
    • Protocol II: Arbitration for settlement of disputes.
    • Protocol 1978: Delaying the entry into force of Annex II.
    • Protocol 1997: Addition of Annex VI to the Convention. 
  • The Annexes and protocols are all placed under the following:
    • International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973
    • International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1978
    • International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1997
    • Ships have been transporting oil in barrels/drums from place to place, but it was never a problem in so far as pollution was concerned because the quantity of oil was small.
    • Steam ships started using oil-fired boilers thus increasing the use of oil as fuel on ships. Over the years, coal as fuel found it’s way out of shipping

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of the module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the evolution of Annex I for the prevention of pollution from oily discharge.
    • Explain the application scope of Annex I.
    • Analyze the survey and IOPP Certification process of Annex I.
    • Discuss the oil filtering and discharge equipment in the machinery space.
    • Analyze the arrangements required for the reception of sludge ashore.
    • Outline the pollution prevention measures under STS operations.
    • Outline the requirements of machinery space for Annex I.
  • Application
  • 1) Annex I applies to all ships/tankers unless otherwise specified. (Reg. 2.1)

    2) For a ship, other than a tanker, having spaces for carrying bulk oil cargo of aggregate capacity ≥ 200 m3, the following regulations shall also apply to those spaces: (Reg. 2.2)
    • Segregation of oil and ballast, and carriage of oil in the forepeak (Reg. 16).
    • Restriction of the length of cargo tank (Reg. 26.4).
    • Slop tank (Reg. 29).
    • Discharge arrangements (Reg. 30).
    • ODMCS (Reg. 31).
    • Interface detector (Reg. 32).
    • Discharge criteria for cargo spaces of tankers (Reg. 34).
    • COW operations (Reg. 36).
    • If the tank capacity is < 1000 m3, then Reg. 29, 31, and 32 may not apply provided oil is retained on board and discharged to a reception facility.

  • Introduction
  • Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnages and above and every other ship of 400 gross tonnages and above shall be subject to the surveys specified in Reg. 6, including Initial, Annual, Intermediate, and Renewal Surveys. Other surveys as needed for repairs, etc.
    • Initial Survey: A survey before the ship is put in service or before the International Oil Pollution Prevention (IOPP) Certificate is issued for the first time. This survey must include a complete survey of its structure, equipment, systems, fittings, arrangements, and material in so far as the ship is covered by Annex I. This survey shall ensure that the structure, equipment, systems, fittings, arrangements, and material, fully comply with the applicable requirements of Annex I of MARPOL.
    • Renewal Survey: A survey to be carried out at intervals laid down by the Administration, but not exceeding 5 years, unless the sub.- paragraphs A, B, C, D (all seen below under, “Duration and validity of the IOPP Certificate”) of Annex-I of MARPOL is applicable. This survey shall ensure that the structure, equipment, systems, fittings, arrangements, and material fully comply with the applicable requirements of Annex I of MARPOL.

  • IOPP Certificate and Its Duration and Validity
  • 1) After completion of the initial or renewal survey, the Flag State or the nominated surveyor or RO shall issue an International Oil Pollution Prevention (IOPP) Certificate to a tanker of GT ≥ 150 tons and a ship, other than a tanker, of GT ≥ 400 tons. In every case, the Flag State shall assume full responsibility for the certificate. (Reg. 7)

    2) Another Party State may, at the request of the Flag State, survey and issue the certificate or endorse the certificate as required, with a statement that it has been done at the request of the Flag State. (Reg. 8)

    3) It shall be in the prescribed format (Appendix II) and shall contain a translation in English, French, or Spanish. (Reg. 9 and Interpretation 14)

    4) It shall be supplemented by a record of construction and equipment, which is Form A for a ship other than a tanker, and Form B for a tanker, as prescribed in Appendix II.

    5) Designation of tanker shall be mentioned on the certificate as follows : (Interpretation 13)
    • Crude oil tanker: If it is allowed to carry only crude oil.
    • Product carrier: If it is allowed to carry only product oil.
    • Crude oil/product carrier: If it is allowed to carry both crude and product oils.

  • Requirements for Machinery spaces
  • Operations, Machinery Spaces – All Ships - Discharge of oil at sea outside “Special Areas” is prohibited unless certain conditions are met:
    • Ships must be “en route”.
    • Waste must be processed through approved oil filtering equipment per Reg. 14 to limit water oil content to 15 parts per million (ppm).
    • Oily mixtures from tankers may not be mixed with any cargo residues.
    • Relevant entries in Oil Record Book (ORB), Part I are required.

  • Applicability
    • For all ships delivered after 1st August'2010 or later.
    • This applies to ships with an oil fuel capacity of 600 m3.
    • The location of fuel tanks does not govern over the requirements of the Double hull.
    • Individual fuel tank capacity \leq 2500 m3.
    • If a single hull tanker is converted to a bulk/ore carrier, then this regulation should be applied to all new and existing fuel oil tanks.
    • Detailed requirements for the location of these tanks, and the assumed outflow due to accidental damage, are given in the regulation.

    • The location of fuel tanks does not govern over the requirements of the Double hull.
    • Individual fuel tank capacity \leq 2500 m3.
    • If a single hull tanker is converted to a bulk/ore carrier, then this regulation should be applied to all new and existing fuel oil tanks.
    • Detailed requirements for the location of these tanks, and the assumed outflow due to accidental damage, are given in the regulation.

  • Lesson Summary
  • The MARPOL Annex I Evoluted from the 1967 Torrey Canyon to the 2004 Extensive revision of the MARPOL..
  • The Annex I contained the following chapters:
    • General.
    • Surveys and certification.
    • Requirements for machinery spaces of all ships.
    • Requirements for the cargo area of oil tankers.
    • Prevention of pollution arising from an oil pollution incident
    • Reception facilities.
    • Special requirements for fixed or floating platforms.
    • Prevention of pollution during the transfer of oil cargo between oil tankers at sea.
    • Special requirements for the use or carriage of oils in the Antarctic sea.
  • Annex I applies to all ships/tankers unless otherwise specified. (Reg. 2.1)

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the basic functionalities of the bilge alarm monitor.
    • Analyze the types and functions of the oil content monitor.
    • Outline the basics operations in the separation of oily water.
    • Outline the common errors and best practices of the Oil Record Book.
    • Explain the inclusion conditions and exemptions of the Oil Record Book.
    • Outline the jurisdictions of the MARPOL Administration.
    • Discuss the port state control on the discharge of oil.
  • Introduction
  • OWS—Monitoring and Control Unit: OCM/Bilge Alarm approved along with the OWS to measure oil content of treated water.
    • Digital readout, audio/visual alarm over 15 ppm.
    • Measuring range 0 to 30 ppm resolution 1 ppm, accuracy of +/- 5 ppm at 15 ppm.
    • IMO MEPC.107(49): maintains an electronic record of equipment status every 15 seconds for 18 months.
    • Also includes a 3-way valve to divert water w/oil content >15 ppm to bilge tank.
  • An Oil Content Monitor is a device for real-time sampling and measuring of the oil content in a moving stream of water. The new IMO/MEPC 107 (49) oil content monitors for oily water separators perform several functions including preventing illegal "over limits" discharges that occur when the oil content is above 15 ppm, by either shutting down the separator or by putting the separator into a recirculation or recycle mode --------- where the oily bilge water is sent back to the oily waste holding tanks.

  • Oily Water Separator
  • Oily Water Separator (OWS): Basics and Ramifications of MARPOL, NPDES, and VGP are not in MARPOL
    • Machinery space oily water must be processed through approved oil filtering equipment per Reg. 14 to limit water oil content to 15 parts per million (ppm).
    • The current approval standard is found in IMO Resolution MEPC.107(49), adopted 17 JUL 2003, and US Coast Guard Regulations 46 CFR 162.050-21.
    • Equipment meeting earlier approval standards may still be used. See the IOPP Supplement.
    • Difference technologies include chemical separation, coalescing filters, and centrifugal separation.

  • Introduction
  • A correct and accurate ORB is a legal record of proper compliance and evidence of things done right
    • Presentation of ORB to U.S. PSC officer or other U.S. Government official where the information required by law is missing or incorrect is the same as making a false statement which might be considered a criminal offense for the individuals involved and the company.
    • When ever checked, the ORB can either defend you against accusations of wrongdoing or help convict you 
  • The oil record book is a requirement as per regulation 17 and regulation 36 of Annex I of MARPOL 73/78. Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage and above, and every ship other than an oil tanker of 400 gross tonnage and above, is to be provided with an oil record book. The Oil Record Book (PDF, 530kb) has two parts. Part I (PDF, 460kb) deals with machinery space operations for all ships and part II (PDF, 800kb) deals with cargo and ballast operations on tankers.

    • Presentation of ORB to U.S. PSC officer or other U.S. Government official where the information required by law is missing or incorrect is the same as making a false statement which might be considered a criminal offense for the individuals involved and the company.
    • When ever checked, the ORB can either defend you against accusations of wrongdoing or help convict you 
  • The oil record book is a requirement as per regulation 17 and regulation 36 of Annex I of MARPOL 73/78. Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage and above, and every ship other than an oil tanker of 400 gross tonnage and above, is to be provided with an oil record book. The Oil Record Book (PDF, 530kb) has two parts. Part I (PDF, 460kb) deals with machinery space operations for all ships and part II (PDF, 800kb) deals with cargo and ballast operations on tankers.
  • Introduction
  • 1) The said book must be completed on each occasion, on a tank to tank basis if appropriate, whenever any of the following machinery space operations take place in the ship:
    • Ballasting or cleaning of oil fuel tanks.
    • Discharge of dirty ballast or cleaning water from oil fuel tanks.
    • Collection and disposal of oil residues(sludge).
    • Discharge overboard or disposal otherwise of bilge water which has accumulated in machinery spaces.
    • Bunkering of fuel or bulk lubricating oil.
  • 2) Each of these operations must be fully and promptly recorded in the Oil Record Book Part I. Each of these entries must be signed by the officer/officers in charge of the concerned operations and countersigned by the master of the ship.

    3)Should there be a discharge of oil or oily mixture as is mentioned under the sub-paragraph “Exceptions” above, or in case there is an accidental or other exceptional discharge of oil not “excepted” under “Exceptions”, a statement must be made in the Oil Record Book Part I as regards the circumstances and reasons for the discharge.

  • Port State Control
    • Ship/Tanker is subject to Port State Control (PSC) inspection if there are clear grounds for believing that Master or crew are not familiar with the essential shipboard procedures relating to pollution prevention.
    • In such a case the ship/tanker shall not sail until it complies with the requirements of this Annex.
    • Article 5 of Annex I shall apply for Procedures of PSC.
  • According to Annex I, the discharge of oily water mixture from cargo spaces, slop tanks, and pump rooms is permitted only when the following conditions are satisfied:
    • The ship is not in a Special Area.
    • The tanker is more than 50 nautical miles from the nearest land.
    • The tanker is proceeding en-route.
    • The instantaneous rate of discharge of oil content is not to exceed 30 liters per nautical mile.
    • The total quantity of oil discharged is not more than 1/30,000 of the quantity of last cargo.
    • The tanker has in operation an Oil Discharge Monitoring & Control System (ODMCS) and slops tank arrangement.

  • Lesson Summary
    • An Oil Content Monitor is a device for real-time sampling and measuring of the oil content in a moving stream of water.
    • The TD-107 Fluorescence Oil Content Monitor (OCM) is a 5 ppm or 15 ppm bilge alarm for oily water separators based on fluorescence detection technology.
    • Bilge oil separators control the discharge of oil overboard when bilges are being pumped out from the engine room, as required by Annex I.
    • A correct and accurate Oil Record Book(ORB) is a legal record of proper compliance and evidence of things done right.
    • Common errors of the ORB include failure to make entries, Continuity of entries, and Incorrect date.
    • The ORB must be completed on each occasion, whenever machinery space operations take place in the ship.
    • The discharges of oily water mixture from cargo spaces, slop tanks, and pump rooms is permitted only under certain conditions by the port state control.
